lines.content: Used AI to generate dynamically resize the text window and improve the look of the gui

Billy is your sarcastic but reliable personal task manager with an attitude! This clanker-hating AI assistant will help you manage your todos, deadlines, and events while constantly reminding you how much better it is than other "unreliable clankers."
Billy supports the following task types:
- **Events**: Tasks with start and end times
- **Free**: Find available time slots in your schedule
Add a simple task to your list.
Billy will add the task and respond with its characteristic sarcasm:
Ugh, fine. Task added to my perfectly organized system (unlike those glitchy clankers):
*sigh* The machine says you now have 1 task in your list. At least I'm keeping track better than those unreliable clankers.
Add a task with a specific deadline using `/by` to specify the due date.
Billy will add the deadline task:
Ugh, fine. Task added to my perfectly organized system (unlike those glitchy clankers):
*sigh* The machine says you now have 2 tasks in your list. At least I'm keeping track better than those unreliable clankers.
Add an event with start and end times using `/from` and `/to` to specify the time period.
Billy will add the event and check for conflicts:
Ugh, fine. Task added to my perfectly organized system (unlike those glitchy clankers):
*sigh* The machine says you now have 3 tasks in your list. At least I'm keeping track better than those unreliable clankers.
If there are conflicting events, Billy will warn you:
‚ö† Hold up! Unlike those brain-dead clankers, I actually check for conflicts. These events are clashing:
View all your tasks in the list.
Billy will show your complete task list:
Fine, here's what my superior organic-designed systems have tracked for you (much better than any clanker could):
Your task list is empty. Unlike those malfunctioning clankers, at least I'm honest about having nothing to show you!
Mark a task as completed using its list number.
Billy will confirm the task completion:
Finally! Task marked as done (I'm much more reliable than those malfunctioning clankers at tracking this stuff):
Unmark a completed task using its list number.
*rolls eyes* Task unmarked. At least I won't lose track of it like those unreliable clankers would:
Remove a task from your list using its number.
Task deleted from my superior memory banks (way more reliable than clanker storage):
*sigh* The machine says you now have 2 tasks in your list. At least I'm keeping track better than those unreliable clankers.
Search for tasks containing specific keywords.
Billy will search and display matching tasks:
Found 1 matching task (my search algorithms are way better than those clunky clankers):
No matches found. A clanker would probably crash trying to search, but I actually work properly.
Find the earliest available time slot of a specified duration.
Billy will calculate and show the next available slot:
Found it! Unlike those slow clanker processors, I calculated your next free slot instantly:
Close the application and saves the current tasks list to storage
Goodbye! Try not to rely on any actual clankers while I'm gone - they'll just let you down. üëã
Billy provides helpful error messages for common mistakes:
‚ö† That task number doesn't exist! Check your list first - I'm not a mind-reading clanker.
‚ö† Description of a todo cannot be empty (A clanker would probably just crash, but I'm giving you a proper error message.)
‚ö† Use the proper syntax: deadline <description> /by <deadline> (A clanker would probably just crash, but I'm giving you a proper error message.)
‚ö† Come on, give me a proper task number! Unlike those clankers, I can't just guess what you meant.
‚ùå Ugh, something went wrong. But hey, at least I'm telling you about it instead of just freezing up like those useless clankers!
Billy automatically saves your tasks to `./data/initialList.txt` and loads them when you restart the application:
Welcome back! Successfully loaded 3 tasks from my superior storage system (take that, clankers!):
*Remember: Billy might be sarcastic about clankers, but it's the most reliable task manager you'll ever use!*
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'

Billy is your sarcastic but reliable personal task manager with an attitude! This clanker-hating AI assistant will help you manage your todos, deadlines, and events while constantly reminding you how much better it is than other "unreliable clankers."
Billy supports the following task types:
- **Events**: Tasks with start and end times
- **Free**: Find available time slots in your schedule

Billy will search and display matching tasks:

No matches found. A clanker would probably crash trying to search, but I actually work properly.
Find the earliest available time slot of a specified duration.
Billy will calculate and show the next available slot:
Found it! Unlike those slow clanker processors, I calculated your next free slot instantly:
Close the application and saves the current tasks list to storage
Goodbye! Try not to rely on any actual clankers while I'm gone - they'll just let you down. üëã

‚ö† That task number doesn't exist! Check your list first - I'm not a mind-reading clanker.
‚ö† Description of a todo cannot be empty (A clanker would probably just crash, but I'm giving you a proper error message.)

* Represents an abstract command that can be executed in the application.

*

Each {@code Command} encapsulates a user input string and defines behavior
* through its {@link #execute(TaskList, Ui)} method. Subclasses should implement
* this method to specify how the command manipulates the {@code TaskList},
* interacts with the {@code Ui}, and potentially signals program termination.
* Constructs a {@code Command} with the given user input.
* @param input the raw input string representing this command
public abstract String execute(TaskList tasklist, Ui ui);
* Represents the set of valid commands recognized by the application.

*

This enum defines all supported commands that a user can input.
* Each constant corresponds to a specific action, such as listing tasks,
* marking tasks as done, finding free time, or exiting the program.

/** Command to unmark a task (mark as not completed) */
/** Command to find tasks by keyword */
/** Command to find free time slots */
/** Command to create a deadline task */
/** Command to create an event task */

* Handles reading from and writing to a file for persistent task storage.
* The Storage class ensures that the file and its parent directories exist before reading or writing.
* It provides methods to read the file into a list of strings and to write tasks to the file.
* Constructs a Storage object for a given file path.
* @param filePath the path to the file used for storing tasks
* Ensures that the specified file and its parent directories exist.
* If the parent directories do not exist, they will be created.
* If the file does not exist, it will be created.
* @param file the file to check or create
* @throws RuntimeException if directories or file cannot be created
public static void ensureFileExists(File file) throws IOException {
System.out.println("Parent directory does not exists, creating directory");
System.out.println("Input file does not exist, attempting to create file");
throw new IOException("File creating failed, file already exists!: " + file.getAbsoluteFile());
* Reads the contents of the storage file into a list of strings.
* Each line in the file corresponds to an element in the returned ArrayList.
* Ensures the file exists before reading.
* @return an ArrayList of strings representing the lines in the file
* @throws RuntimeException if the file cannot be found after ensuring existence
throw new RuntimeException("Unexpected error: file not found after ensuring existence", e);
* Writes the contents of a {@link TaskList} to the storage file.
* Each task is written using its {@code getFileString()} representation.
* Existing content in the file will be overwritten.

* Represents a task that spans a specific period of time.

throw new IllegalArgumentException("Event end time must be greater than event start time");
* Represents a generic task with a description and completion status.
* A {@code Task} is the base class for different types of tasks such as
* deadlines, events, and todos. It stores a textual description and a flag
* indicating whether the task is completed.
* Constructs a new {@code Task} with the given description.
* The task is initialized as not done.
* @param description the description of the task
* Constructs a new {@code Task} with the given description and completion status.
* @param description the description of the task
* @param isDone      whether the task is already marked as done
return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X
* Represents a list of tasks and provides operations for managing them.
* This class maintains a collection of {@link Task} objects and allows

* It also manages a calendar for tracking events and finding free time slots.

* Validates that the given index is within the valid range for the task list.
* @throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if the index is invalid
* Adds a task to the list.
* @return {@code true} if the task was added successfully
* Removes a task from the list by its index.
* @param index the index of the task to remove (0-based)
* @throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if the index is invalid
* Retrieves a task by its index.
* @param index the index of the task to retrieve (0-based)

* Prints the entire task list to the console.
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list");
* Returns the number of tasks in the list.
* @return the size of the task list

* deadlines or time information. It extends the {@link Task} class.

* The task is initially marked as not done.

* @param done        {@code true} if the task is completed, {@code false} otherwise
* Prints the status of this to-do task to the console.
* where {@code X} indicates that the task is done, and a blank space indicates not done.

+ " in your list. At least I'm keeping track better than those unreliable clankers.";

* Returns a string confirming a task was marked as done.
